title: Are autistic people hard to read for other people? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on the person with autism and the person interacting with them. If the person interacting with the autistic person knows them well they can probably read them about as well as any other person because they have learned how the autistic person responds differently and how they respond similarly to allistics. A lot of non-autistics tend to view lack of eye contact as a sign of being deceptive. Many autistics are not good at eye contact. A lot of non-autistics tend to view lack of basic social interaction skills (for example: talking over people instead of doing back and forth conversation, sticking to limited topics the other person isn’t interested in, interupting, not following conversation shifts, not being competent at small talk) as rude and inconsiderate. Many autistics are very passionate about their topics and have trouble understanding that not everyone else is. Many also don’t get the point of “small talk”. A lot of non-autistics expect certain physical movements in conjunction with conversation as a sign the other person is engaged. Many autistics neither know nor care about that aspect of communication. Most non-autistics expect a certain level of deception in thier conversations, ie “white lies.” Many autistics either don’t lie or lie poorly and often don’t see the point of “white lies” to begin with. You can see, based on this, that if a non-autistic is interacting with an autistic person and expecting the other person to behave as though they are non-autistic then it would be very easy to misread the autistic person’s interactions. If the non-autistic person doesn’t know the other person is autistic then they will expect them to behave in the same way as every other non-autistic person they have interacted with. Autistic people who have learned to mask by following non-autistic social interaction skill can also misread an autistic person who hasn’t done so. So, yes, autistic people can be hard to read for people that do not personally know them well.

One of the core aspects of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is social dysfunction. This can manifest in a range of behaviors, from completely avoiding any sort of personal interaction at all… to completely monopolizing conversations on a single topic that nobody other than the person speaking seems to be very interested in. There is no fixed pattern to social dysfunction, but it’s almost always one of the major identifiers of ASD and often the one that stands out the most when interacting with someone on the spectrum. For high-functioning autistic individuals, these social skills deficits can be so minor as to be almost entirely unnoticeable in casual conversation. People with HFA (high-functioning autism) commonly adopt coping methods or have the ability to acquire social skills to fit in better. They are often able, with proper training (which often includes components of applied behavior analysis), to make significant progress in social interactions. Nonetheless, at some level, even high-functioning autistics almost always struggle with some discomfort or ineptitude in social interactions. Understanding the Connection Between Social Skills and Autism All of these social skills problems are rooted in some of the basic elements of ASD: Delays and difficulty in acquiring verbal communication skillsInability to read non-verbal communication cuesRepetitive or obsessive behaviors and insistence on an adherence to fixed routineOverwhelming sensory inputsThese combinations of traits make it enormously difficult for ASD patients to acquire the basic social skills that most of us take for granted. This deficit is often misread as a desire to avoid people or social situations, but that couldn’t be further from the truth: most individuals with ASD badly want to interact with others, they simply don’t have the skillset to do so easily. This, in turn, can breed frustration that only fuels the fire. People on the spectrum may have outbursts and throw tantrums or express themselves inappropriately in social contexts, essentially as a result of boiling over at their difficulty to either understand their place in a social situation or make themselves understood to others. At the opposite end of the spectrum, but equally rooted in social skills deficits, some with ASD are unable to fully grasp their own communication issues and often fail to recognize how their way of communicating can be offensive or make others feel uncomfortable. These types of social missteps manifest in obliviousness—monopolizing conversations, being unable or unwilling to converse outside particular topic areas, or generally shutting out all external stimulus. Dealing With Social Skills Issues in ASD Patients It’s difficult to deal with social dysfunction because social skills cover such a broad gamut of capabilities. These include: Verbal and non-verbal communicationAnalytical and inferential skillsSensory perceptionUnderstanding of context in social situationsThere is limited research on the outcomes for social skills training but what exists suggest that it is hampered by a failure to emphasize social skill development and implement it effectively. A 2007 meta-analysis by Indiana University of 55 social skills intervention programs used in school-age ASD populations found that they were largely ineffective. Not surprisingly, social skills training that took place when autistic students were segregated from the general student population was far less effective than if it took place in their usual classroom alongside neurotypical kids – as if a study was needed to figure that out. Nonetheless, school programs were found to be more effective than programs offered in other contexts, which suggests that training social skills in social environments—a naturalistic approach often used in ABA therapy—shows the most promise. And some therapists have suggested that most ABA therapy aimed at improving social skills simply isn’t intense and immersive enough to help patients develop more socially appropriate behavior and abandon bad social habits and responses. As humans, we’re all social animals to a greater or lesser degree, so the importance of being able to thrive – or at least function – in normal social settings is fundamentally key to happiness and a normal human experience. As ABAs work to address things like cognition and communication skills, positive outcomes in these areas are sure to translate to improved social skills and a better quality of life. Autistic people are hard for autistic people to read, man! Just ask my girlfriend and me! The fact is that, “doesn’t understand some social cues,” can mean literally thousands of very different things. My gf doesn’t get chit-chat. I love chit-chat with my favorite people! I get sad when I don’t know how to strike up a good conversation with someone — especially with my gf! But she taught me to chill ☺️ I don’t get jealousy. I have to be super careful to check in with all my partners, gf included, possibly-on-the-spectrum others included, to make sure I don’t give the impression of favoring someone or ignoring someone else. Or complimenting someone else too much in front of them… NTs have trouble reading me because: I’m not what they’ve come to expect.I mask really well, and I can’t always turn it off. I will smile when I’m deeply uncomfortable. Even if I’d rather, y’know, give my NT friend some proper social cues as to how I’m feeling. I can’t just choose that option.Hope that helps! Katie❤️⭐️

They can be. The standard narrative is that Autistic people have a varied of deficits that lead to both their inability to read others. In recent years it’s become clear that it goes the other way as well. You could easily point to deficits in expression of the autistic people to explain this, but that’s not the full story. When two or more autistic people come together, it’s been shown that they don’t have the same deficits with each other. This raises the alternate narrative that it’s not as simple as autistic communication is just “wrong” but rather that it’s also “different,” and to a certain extent we’re also looking at a translation issue.

Some respondents to this question will be autism professionals, very few of whom know what it is like to be autistic. They judge autism from the things they observe, with no idea of what is really going on. They will talk to you about dysfunction and deficit when we often have unusual abilities. If you get responses from Autistics who may also be professionals, you are likely to get very different responses. Your question is a good one and the answer does not lie in telling you that autistics are socially dysfunctional. They are different and many of their unusual behaviours are being found to be functional with regard to different brain structure. So yes, Autistics can be hard for non autistics to read, just as they are hard for us to read.

When you’ve met one person with autism, you’ve met one person with autism. Your mileage may vary. Personally, I’ve found that I am very hard for the average person to get a read on when I’m not emulating typical body language. I have my own kind of body language which is very different from a neurotypical. I don’t smile, frown, or have open body language. I have my own things that I do that people close to me have come to understand and learn. I imagine that many other autistics are the same way. Many autistics have difficulty understanding and responding to social cues which is another part of the reason why people find it difficult to get a reading on us. It puts people on edge because they don’t know what we’re thinking or feeling. On the other hand, it’s fairly easy for me to get a read on most neurotypical people due to my years of studying them. There’s two sides to this coin.

In my opinion, yes. Autistic people can be as hard to read for NTs as it can be for us to read them. Some of us lack the depth and variety of facial expressions and body language, which can cause someone to misread the “social cues” we have no idea we’re putting out. The best example of this I can think of is the popular term ‘resting bitch face’. I’m told I look angry or bored all the time, when that’s usually not how I feel. It definitely goes both ways as far as the miscommunication factor.

Yes, they are. One of major concerns of diagnosing (understanding) autism is not why they are lining up toys or obsessing over specific topics/objects . But it’s lack of understanding social cues. For most of us it's easy to just glance at one another to read the behavioral or the social cues that are occuring, while autistic people have a hard time understanding what is going on at given time.

Yes. It often begins with a few uncomfortable ASD sensory traits, and then it escalates from social intolerance of their sensitivities. Many are uncomfortable with maintaining eye and face contact from birth. Since learning to make facial expressions requires looking at faces, that's one trait that works against developing this particular aspect of common allistic society communication. Projecting honest feelings and thoughts often has led young children with ASD to be persecuted, punished, and invalidated repeatedly until they shut down or learn some way to fake it. In response, many will learn to mask everything they think and feel from showing outwardly.

Yes. Many, if not most, people with autism are more difficult to read than others. Not just for neurotypical people, but perhaps even more difficult for others with autism. People frequently have trouble telling when I’m joking or being serious or what emotion I’m trying to express.
